items.content: I'm a naturally happy and outgoing person. I'm also very curious and not afraid to ask questions. I'm comfortable both with being sociable and working entirely on my own.

I enjoy helping people. I've posted answers on Stack Overflow and I often join a server on Discord where I help people with questions about programming. I've also tutored mathematics in the real world. I've been told I'm patient when teaching and explain things well.

I'm passionate about taking responsibility for a given task. I rarely start implementing a solution until I understand the goal of the task. I'm persistent and I'll keep the ball rolling until the task is clarified, completed, tested, delivered, and verified. If that requires administrative tasks, like getting access to a company resource, then I view that as part of the task.
I enjoy the process from start to finish, which especially includes, but is not limited to:

content: Talking to uses and other stakeholders
Collaborating on finding options & solutions for everyone's benefit

items.content: While writing documentation isn't my favourite part of software development, I find it to be just as important as any other part. This includes user guides, both for end users, but also documentation on how to use a library. I believe the energy spent on creating software is wasted if nobody understands how to use it.
My overall goal is to enjoy the process and have fun with it.
I have project goals. The project becomes my "mission" and I'll do what is in my power to see the project goals complete.

I have no preference between maintaining an existing system and being part of the team that creates a completely new one. In my experience maintaining an already existing system often requires adding new features. I take as much pleasure in fixing bugs as making something brand new.

I've found that my strengths are also my weaknesses. I can be perfectionistic, which at times is the enemy of "good enough". It can also save a lot of time revisiting the same feature over and over fixing bugs. I'm more inclined to "get it right the first time" than to "get a head start and ship it early".

I'd like to know and remember everything, but I'm also aware that's it's not possible. I try to find a balance between the two by knowing enough to enable me to be productive and knowing how to easily find out details when I need it. For me, that means I'm often fuzzy on the details, and I'll have to make a quick lookup in the documentation.

I'm adaptive to change. If I need to learn a new language, a new tool, or use a different procedure, I'll be happy to learn and use it. However, I find it much more motivating to understand the reasoning for the change, even when I think trying out new technology in itself is fun.

include: Puzzles
Woodworking
